source.222f0a4f:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(4,2, figsize=(16,16))
sns.distplot(df.Age, bins = 20,ax=ax[0,0],color='r',kde=True) 
sns.distplot(df['Number of Times Pregnant'], bins = 20,ax=ax[0,1],color='b') 
sns.distplot(df['Plasma Glucose concentration'], bins = 20,ax=ax[1,0],color='g') 
sns.distplot(df['Diastolic BP'], bins = 20,ax=ax[1,1],color='y') 
sns.distplot(df['Triceps skin Fold'], bins = 20,ax=ax[2,0],color='pink')
sns.distplot(df['Serum Insulin'], bins = 20,ax=ax[2,1],color='orange')
sns.distplot(df['Diabetes Pedigree'], bins = 20,ax=ax[3,0],color='violet') 
sns.distplot(df['BMI'], bins = 20,ax=ax[3,1],color='black')

source.c52e48a5: From above output we can conclude that the person having average plasma glucose concentration near to 141 or more are more likely to have a diabetes beacuse normal range is from 100mg/dl to 140mg/dl
source.bb4f2c51: In above output we can conclude that as our BMI increases chances of diabetes also increases, an ideal BMI is in the 18.5 to 24.9 range. For children and young people aged 2 to 18, the BMI calculation takes into account age and gender as well as height and weight.
source.d998c0ef: Age, DiabetesPedigree, Serum Insulin, Number of Times Pregnant found to be exponentially distributed.
source.573381c5:
Attributes BMI, Diastolic BP, Plasma Glucose concentration are found to be normally distributed.
BMI and Diastolic BP nearly have Gaussian distribution
